Brief Synopsis:

The gangs latest mystery takes them 3 miles outside Crystal Cove to Gatorsburg, where the danger is heightened.

Bad Guy In a Mask:

The Gator People

Episode Review:

The episode opens with a station wagon pulling into a run down, shabby town.

The family inside are headed for New Yorkwhich, according to the daughter is 2000 miles from where they are now. Realizing that they will need more gas, the father pulls over at a gas station to refuel.

The family dog, Petals, gets out and looks around only for them to discover scary gator people who chase them out of the town.

Meanwhile back in Crystal Cove, its raining and the gang are hanging out at Freds house, bored out of their minds.

Daphne discovers Freds copy of Traps Illustrated and gives him a hard time over it. He points out thats how he created his new trap, that successfully traps the delivery guy.

The delivery guy has a package from Mr. E. Inside is a letter stating that he had been saving this for a rainy day.

Inside the package is a handbag made out of gator skin, with a label reading 100 % Gator. Made in Gatorsburg. Daphne, ever the fashionista, claims that that cant be right, Gatorsburg hasnt manufactured anything with Gator in decades.

Velma goes more in depth, explaining that during the 1800s, a group of prospectors were looking for goldbut found alligator. The town witnessed a boon as they made all sort of gator skin products, like hats, shoes, and corsets. Unfortunately, the gator wells ran dry, and Gatorsburg became a ghost town.

With all this information, they decide to go to Gatorsburg and investigate.

They arrive at the ghost town, causing Velma to quip This is what happens when a civilization is founded entirely on a gator-based economy.

Naturally, the first decision is to split up and look for clues. Shaggy, Scooby and Velma head towards Gator Burger and discover that there is an entire supply of burgers sitting under an old hot lamp.

Naturally, they decide to eat the burgers. Velma keeps trying to get Shaggy alone so that they can talk. Shaggy says he cant because of how hungry he is. Velma, understandably, is upset by this and storms off. While Shaggy is attempting to understand her issue, Fred declares there is absolutely nothing worth investigating, much less trapping, and that they can leave.

However, upon returning to the Mystery Machine, they discover that someone, or something, has stolen their engine.

Fortunately, a mechanic pulls up beside them. He tells them that he can indeed get a new engine, but since Crystal Cove is over 3 miles away, theyll be forced to spend the night.

The gang attempts to call their parents, but each one has some reason why they cant come to rescue their children. Horse races, the fact its darkor most disturbingly, its Still Life Night.

Grady tells them that they can spent the night at the only hotel, The Drowsy Gator. His sister Greta is the owner, and he warns them that they shouldnt leave their rooms.

As they approach, Scooby-Doo notices that the sign changes from a normal hotel sign

to a threat.

The hotel itself is kinda shabbyand has the air that maybe once it was less shabby. A strange out-of-tune piano is playing in the background. The owner, Greta, tries to give them the runaround. Claiming that they have no rooms, or that the painted sign is broken.

With the gang undeterred, she calls her son Gunter (whos been playing the piano) and introduces him. They both give creepy laughs and in general are creepy. Finally she takes them upstairs.

She gives the gang the rules of the hotel. Boys and girls have separate rooms, prompting the first of a few jokes about Velma not being girly. Then she reiterates her brothers warning to stay in their rooms, regardless of what they hear, up to and including, a body being dragged across a hardwood floor. Oh, and by the way, no pets allowed.

Dejectedly, Scooby-Doo heads down to the Mystery Machine for the evening.

Meanwhile, Velma is primping and plans to sneak over to Shaggys room for some alone time. Daphne is suspicious.

Fred, on the other hand, starts asking Shaggy about what kind of beds they should get when the gang move in together after high school. Shaggy is having none of it because he is worried about Scooby-Doo.

Shaggy and Velma bump into each other in the hallway. Shaggy tries to play it off like that was his intention all along. Daphne shows up at Fred and Shaggys room looking for Velma. Fred says they arent there, but he has something for her. Its a scrapbookof traps theyve had.

Meanwhile, in the Mystery Machine, Scooby-Doo is attacked by the three Gator People.

Scooby-Doo manages to evade them and escape into the hotel, where he meets up with Daphne and Fred. The three are pursued by the Gators through the hallways.

Eventually, the three reunite with Shaggy and Velma, and they exit the hotel, with the gator people in pursuit. However, during the chase, they learn that the Gators must not be real gators, but people in a costume when one loses a limb.

They finally escape the Gators by pushing the Mystery Machine down hill and hoping on. However, they also realize that the Gators werent trying to kill them, just chase them out of town.

Returning to the town to investigate, they discover the Gators are loading crates onto boats. Inside the crates are items labeled 100% Gator

however upon further inspection, Daphne proves that the items are imitation alligator skin, as she has an allergy to fake animal products.

The gang naturally sets a trap and captures the Gators.

The Sheriff arrives and they unmask the Gator Family. The Gators were determined to stay in Gatorsburg, so they created their ruse to allow themselves the money to stay. Since enough time had passed since the town was abandoned, there was plenty of time for it to seem like the Alligators had returned.

They proclaim that they would have gotten away with it, if it werent for those meddling juviniles and their unauthorized investigation of our synthetic gator accessories.

Then, Sheriff Stone laments that he bought a Gator Skin Track Suitand that it doesnt breathe. He has them arrested even though he technically has no jurisdiction.

The gang returns to the van to discover their engine has been replaced, with a note from Mr. E that states:

Hope you had a good time in Gatorsburg. But be warned, there are more mysteries to come. This is only one piece of the puzzle.

Thunder claps and everyone stands around staring. Shaggy takes Velmas hand as the episode draws to a close.

Relevant Clues to the Curse of Crystal Cove:

1. Gatorsburg. While it isnt a major player in the Curse, it does hold something very important in itbut that isnt until Season 2.

2. The Sign at the Inn. The Dog Dies! comes back in an oblique reference that most people would forget, especially given the erratic airing schedule on CN.

Mayor Dads Strange Statements:

Malevolent Mushroom Caps

My Thoughts:

Were now into the second episode of the series, and our formula is starting to appear. Standard format of mystery with clues towards the bigger mystery. Some episodes have more clues than others. This ones are only slightly important to the overall mystery.

This episode also paints a picture of what the rest of the series is going to be like in terms of tone. The Gator People are legitimately terrifying. The lack of light in most of the attack scenes, with only mood lighting to illuminate the action is strikingly effective. Even in Zombie Island the danger was never as severe or intense.

The writing is also pretty sharp. They find a way to juxtapose the comedy while keeping things tense and scary. Particularly effective is Gretas scene when shes telling the kids the rules of the hotel. Her over-the-top ersatz Cajun/southern accent manages to strike the balance of funny with menace. Its like Paula Deen meets The Evil Queen.

Equally impressive is the use of color. The hallways and lobby of The Drowsy Gator are swathed in this strange pink-red color, that gives it an eerie effect, particularly in contrast to the subdued greens and blues of the bedrooms.

The character development in this episode is front and centerto a degree. Daphne and Fred are left in the same place they were in the pilot. Shes in love and hes clueless. Its Velma and Shaggys relationship that gets the coloring in this episode. In someways its a re-hash of the pilot as well. You see Shaggy side with Scooby-Doo and not want to hurt his feelings. You see Velma trying to seduce Shaggy. However, its more evident in this episode that Shaggy really does have feelings for Velma. Its the awkward first relationship where you want to be with someone, but are afraid your best friend will be hurt or alienated. The only difference is, for most of us, our best friend is not an anthropomorphic dog.

Overall the strengths of this episode are the strengths of the series itself. Sharp writing, paired with solid voice work and incredibly impressive visuals. This one was a little tamer in terms of the comedy or the pop-culture references, which is something thats needed. The show strikes that balance very well.

The next episode brings back Angel Dynamite (a favorite of mine), as well as one of the more unusual bad guys the franchise has ever had.

Pop-Culture References:

The family featured in the cold opening is a direct reference to the Griswolds in the National Lampoons Family series of movies, down to having Beverly DAngelo voice the mother.

Traps Illustrated is a take on Sports Illustrated, in particular the annual Swimsuit Edition.

The Gator Miner is actually Nugget Nose, the Galloping Ghost from the short-lived Buford and The Galloping Ghost. I had to look this one up.

The mechanics truck looks very similar to the truck featured in the thriller Duel, which gets an even larger reference in the next episode.

The monsters Fred references in his scrapbook of traps are The Phantom of Vasquez Castle from Hassle in the Castle (Episode 103 of SDWAY) and Carlotta the Gypsy from A Gaggle of Galloping Ghosts (Episode 111 of SDWAY).

Brief Synopsis:

We are introduced to a group of teens who solve mysteries in their hometown of Crystal Covehowever things are not always what they seem.

Bad Guy In a Mask:

The Slime Mutant

Episode Review:

The series, and episode, begins with the gang cheering over a job well done solving their latest mystery.

Unfortunately, the towns sheriff, Bronson Stone is less than thrilled, and has them locked up in jail. Stone reminds them that he is the sheriff, and that is why he wears the badge (Velma gets in some good snark here). He informs them that he has called their parents on speed-dial and that Fred should be sure to tell his dad, the mayor, hello.

Dejectedly, Fred comments that At least we arent in this to be liked, although neither he or the rest of the gang seem to truly feel that way.

Were treated to the new opening credits, which introduces the main cast and something specific about them. Fred likes traps. Daphne likes Fred. Velma likes laptops. Shaggy and Scooby-Doo like food. This is the last time these will be mentioned in the actual review.

We are in a new day, and Velma is guiding tourists on the Crystal Cove Haunted Tour. It is here that she gives the tourists (and us) a brief overview of the towns history: In 1630, a group of Spanish Conquistadors mysteriously disappeared Where did they go? asks one tourist, to which Velma snarks What part of the word mystery didnt you understand?

She continues, telling them that in 1765, an entire town of missonairies also disappeared. Things went along smoothly until 1865 when Cletus Darrow found Gold and renamed the town Crystal Cove. Most thought the Curse had been lifted, however one Halloween, the Darrow family also mysteriously disappeared. Velma pulls out a tape player and plays a recording of a woman screaming. So much shade is thrown in this first exchange, its ridiculous.

She then guides the tourists inside the museum, telling them that since the disapperance of the Darrow family, the town has been a hub of paranormal activitiy. She takes them by statues of previous monsters that she and her friends have unmasked are displayed. They include Charlie the Robot, Miner 49er, Space Kook, Captain Cutlers Ghost, The Creeper, and The Luna Ghost. The tourists exclaim that they must have been terrifying, to which Velma finally comes to life as she details how they were all fakeor tries to.

Her parents, Angie and Dale, arrive to hush her up and move the tourists on to the Haunted Snack Shop for souvenirs and [their] complimentary undead sipper cup. The tourists eagerly rush off. Angie and Dale chastize Velma for exposing the truth. They truly believe that Crystal Cove is full of paranormal activity, which Velma very clearly doesnt. She states that there is only one thing her generation is interested in and thats

a fast cut to Fred tying his ascot on proclaiming Solving mysteries and building traps. This is much to his father, Mayor Dads chagrin. His dad wants Fred to set an example. Fred just wants to build traps and find answers. Mayor Dad tells Fred that life isnt about all of that its really about

Food. Specifically, pancakes, bacon, sausages and orange juice. At least, thats what Shaggy and Scooby-Doo think. Shaggys parents, Paula and Colton (who is sort of emasculated), are ashamed of his slacker behavior and the mystery solving behavior. They want him to find new friends. Shaggy attempts to tell them that theyre over-reacting and to give the gang a chance

becuase theyre just solving mysteries. And all the kids are doing it. Or so Daphne attempts to tell her parents, Nan and Barty. We learn that Daphne is quite well off financially, but she is also a disappointment to her familyas her four older sisters have highly respectable careers and husbands.

Suddenly, a horn honks and the lengthy exposition of the characters is over. We cut to some underground area of some sort and a construction crew is drilling into rock. Suddenly, one of them falls through a brick wall, revealing caves and tunnels behind it.

They investigate, and naturally run into several canisters of radioactive waste clearly marked DANGER. One of the canisters, naturally, is moving. Naturally, the foreman says that whatever is inside is clearly dangerous and it must be opened so that whatever *is* inside doesnt disrupt their schedule. Of course, this is the first encounter with The Slime Mutant.

The next scene has the gang driving to school in The Mystery Machine. Velma and Shaggy are riding in the back, and we learn that the two are secretly dating. Secretly, because Shaggy is worried that Scooby-Doo will get jealous of the relationship. Velma wants to tell Scooby-Doo now.

But, before she can a manhole cover suddenly explodes up from the ground and they are attacked by The Slime Mutant.

Fred, sensing a mystery is at hand, declares it more important than school and they start to investigate. They find themselves in the caves and discover the canisters. Velma states that based on the oxidation, theyre between 30 and 40 years old.

Daphne discovers a strange magnifying glass shaped locket. Inside is a faded picture of a boy and girl in 1960s clothes. The locket plays a mysterious tune when opened. Fred congratulates her on finding the clue, and we learn that he is completely oblivious to Daphnes feelings.

Shortly thereafter, the gang discovers the construction workers trapped on the ceiling, encased in a lime green cocoon of ickiness. The gang call Sheriff Stone. Stone tells them that this is a crime scene and that he is in charge.

Fred attempts to talk to Stone, but instead winds up stealing one of the bodies. He decides they need to visit Professor Emmanuel Raffalo, the Biology teacher at Crystal Cove High.

Professor Raffalo informs them that the construction worker isnt dead, merely in a dehydrated stasis. He asks to keep the body to perform further analysis as the gang heads out to keep investigating.

The gang, at Shaggy and Scooby-Doos request, go to Fruitmiers, a new smoothie/yogurt/soft serve combo, that is lime green. Even Franklin Fruitmier, the creator, isnt sure what it is. Fred suggests that if the cocoon is indeed organic, they might actually have a legitimate paranormal occurence. Velma offers up some science-babble and attempts to hold Shaggys handwhich of course freaks him out. Daphne asks Velma if something is going on between them, which causes an outburst as Velma stalks off. Daphne again attempts flirting with Fredand he again is oblivious (or at least seemingly).

In the High School Biology Lab, Professor Raffalo is analyzing the cocoon, when he is suddenly attacked by The Slime Mutant.

The scene changes to the local AM Radio Station, K-Ghoul, where the DJ, Angel Dynamite is letting Fred hang out. He feels guilty about what happened to the Professor. The gang attempts to cheer him up. They remind him that hes never walked away from a mystery before.

Velma tries to tell him that shes brought a sample of the cocoon, only to discover that Scooby-Doo is eating it. Of course. Scooby-Doo tells them that its actually Fruitmiers and totally edible. Angel Dynamite tactfully informs the group that If that dog mutates, Im puttin it down. Dig?

Shaggy also tries the cocoon and reassures the gang that it is indeed Fruitmeirs. This means that The Slime Mutant must not be a real monster after all. The gang starts to suspect that Franklin Fruitmeir is the bad guy, and conveniently he is hiring new female assistants

which inevitably leads to Shaggy and Scooby-Doo having to cross dress, because Daphne and Velma refuse. That night, Shaggy and Scooby-Doo let the rest of the gang into Fruitmeirs shop, and they start to investigate.

This leads to another brief encounter with The Slime Mutant. Daphne ends up trapped in a storage closet, and then falls through a trap in the floor. Naturally.

This, however leads them to the cave system they found earlier. They discover another hole only a few feet from the first one, which is directly below the Crystal Cove Bank. (Convenient, no?) With that, they start to plan the capture of The Slime Mutant.

In true Fred Jones fashion, he creates an elaborate Rube Goldman trap, which almost goes off without a hitch.

However, the gang does manage to get the upper hand and they cocoon The Slime Mutant to the wall. Stone and Mayor Dad show up on cue and accuse them of hijacking their latest tourist attraction.

The gang accuse Franklin Fruitmeir, but are surprised when it turns out to actually be Professor Raffalo.

Professor Raffalo tells them that he was using the disguise so he could steal money from the bank. Daphne momentarily questions this aloud, before realizing that hes a teacher and of course he needs the money.

He declares that his plan would have worked if it wasnt for those meddling kids and their blasted dog. Stone takes him away. Daphne asks Professor Raffalo about the locket, but he knows nothing about it, however there is a strange flash of recognition on Mayor Dads face.

Stone chastises them for taking away their new stream of revenue.

Back at K-Ghoul, the gang are celebrating and listening to some groovy tunes, when a call comes in. The mysterious caller tells them that they are all doomed. He identifies himself as Mr. E, and tells them that they should never brought the locket out of the cave. That they have started to unravel the true mystery, a mystery that should have stayed buriedforever.

Relevant Clues to the Curse of Crystal Cove:

1. Daphnes Discovery of the Locket. It will eventually be revealed who the boy and girl are.

2. The Introduction of Mr. E. He becomes vital to the series.

Mayor Dads Strange Statements:

1. Tickling Chitwhiskers

2. Hopping Steamclamps

My Thoughts:

Where to start? I guess with some of the more obvious things first. This is most likely the only time it wont just be a straight review, as there is a LOT to discuss in terms of changes made for the re-boot.

Crystal Cove

This is the first franchise where the gangs hometown is not Coolsville. The town is renamed Crystal Cove and is dubbed The Most Hauntedest Place on Earth. Why its called Crystal Cove when its where gold was found, Ill never know.

Presumably we are somewhere in Northern California. Well learn later that they arent too far from mountains, and given that they solved the case of Miner 49er sometime prior to the start of the series, they have to be somewhere close to San Francisco. There is a very heavy Spanish influence to the towns architecture as well.

Interestingly, when I first watched the show and wasnt paying attention to context clues and history, I assumed that this probably took place in the Pacific Northwest, where I always felt the original series (before they started to really go places) was somewhere in New England.

There is no way to speculate when exactly this series would be set chronologically (as evidenced in a few later episodes).

Time Period/Design Elements

This is a bit trickier to narrow down. Presumably, it is set in the present day, based on the amount of technology available to the gang and bad guys. The fashions and color schemes, however, suggest that the town is stuck in a retro-world.

For the most part, the characters have been reverted back to their original 1969 costumes. The most obvious change being that Velma now has two little red bows in her hair.

The series has its very own unique design. The textures and colors are much different than what we saw in the classic series. Frankly, I am all for it.

Characters

The characters have developed some since 1969. Shaggy and Scooby-Doo largely remain the same. Fred has kind of become a lovable oaf, where in the original series he was more non-descript. Daphne, still slightly danger prone, is no longer the dumber of the two women. Shes actually one of the more mature team members, and by openly giving her a wealthy family (something merely suggested in early incarnations), it does set up a difference between them. Velma has largely remained the same, but is significantly snarkier than before.

The fact that the cast are very definitely in high school is also a change. In previous incarnations, they had all already graduated. Frankly, I like this aspect a lot. For one, it makes them a little more relatable, and it keeps things from getting too strange. I also think it forced the writers to be more creative when they couldnt suddenly take them off to Japan, or Scotland, or Djiboutti.

The Episode

The episode itself is a little slow to start. Theres a LOT of exposition that has to go into the first few minutes, and honestly, it barrells through it. We learn that the town wants to profit off of the so-called mosnters, we learn that their parents dont get them, and we learn about their romantic intanglements.

At first, I was kinda put off by the romantic subplots with everyone. Sure, Daphne and Fred had been in a defacto relationship from the get go, but the idea of Velma/Shaggy was a new concept that the series introduced. Thankfully, this series handles the Velma/Shaggy plot with a LOT more maturity and dignity than the awful Scooby-Doo: The Curse of the Lake Monster from a little later in 2010.

I honestly can not rave about the characterization of this show more. They develop everyone so fully that you dont think of them as just being a group of stock characters, but characters with some interesting shading.

Similarly, I was originally not too pleased to hear Patrick Warburtons voice. I do enjoy him, but didnt necessarily want to see him in the franchise, however Sheriff Stone is a welcome addition to the franchise (as are several of the other major characters they introduce).

The plot is pretty standard, and honestly, with as much changing as they did to the series, Im kind of glad for it. Having the familiarity of Bad Guy in Mask and the inevitable Meddling Kids comment, keeps the show from seeming like a complete and total overhaul, something a lot of reboots seem to miss. The fact that they actually gave a plausible background for Prof. Raffalo was pretty nice. It wasnt your Oh, Im doing it because I want money, it was Im doing this because Im a teacher and make squatt.

I also really loved the nods to the classic series. I never cared much for the redesigns, so having everyone back in their real outfits was something that automatically drew me to the series. The sly injokes will continue throughout the series.

Small details like these are part of what make this series so great and stand out among the other series in the franchise.

The next episode is actually one of my favorites, The Creeping Creatures.

Pop-Culture References:

In the opening scenes of the tour, one of the tourists is clearly patterned after Don Knotts. Knotts partnered up with Scooby-Doo and company twice before in The New Scooby-Doo Movies.

The statues are all former bad guys, mostly from Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!, however The Luna Ghost is from the 2002 Live-Action film Scooby-Doo.

As if it wasnt obvious, the joke about a teacher needing to rob a bank is a little too on the nose.
